title: How to Throw Away a Trash Can

steps.title: Call 311.
steps.content: Call 311. Use a local phone to call 311 and contact your local government. Ask them if there is any region-specific information about garbage can disposal that you should be aware of before disposing. Your local government may ask you to call your local waste disposal group to alert them that you will be throwing away a large item.

steps.title: Put your trash can on the curb.
steps.content: Put your trash can on the curb. Make sure you follow your local laws and place the trash can in an appropriate location. Most cities require that trash cans are placed at least 3 feet (0.91 m) away from the nearest car. If your trash can has wheels, place the trash can so the wheels face towards your house.

steps.title: Turn your trash can upside down.
steps.content: Turn your trash can upside down. This lets your local waste disposal group know that the trash can is empty. [1] X Research source

steps.title: Fashion a sign that says “Discard”.
steps.content: Fashion a sign that says “Discard”. Make sure your sign is legible and large. Place it on the trash can. Secure with tape or twine if necessary. You can also spray paint a message directly onto the trash can, such as “Please take me” or “Take this can too.”

steps.title: Cut your trash can into pieces.
steps.content: Cut your trash can into pieces. If your trash can has not been successfully picked up after a trash run, use a saw or large knife to cut the bin into smaller pieces, then place it in a normal trash bag for removal. This method generally only works for plastic trash cans.

steps.title: Find your local recycling center.
steps.content: Find your local recycling center. Locate your local recycling center on www.iwanttoberecycled.org. Find out if they recycle trash cans, and bring your trash can to their location if they do. If your trash can doesn’t fit in your car, or if you don’t have a car, ask if they have a pick-up service.

steps.title: Take your metal trash can to a scrap metal recycling facility.
steps.content: Take your metal trash can to a scrap metal recycling facility. Locate your nearest scrap metal recycling facility on www.gotscrap.com. Note that there’s a chance there isn’t a scrap metal recycling facility near you. If there is, bring your metal trash can to this location, where you can even get paid for recycling !

steps.title: Donate your trash can.
steps.content: Donate your trash can. Contact your local nonprofit organizations and ask if they take donated trash cans for families in need. If they do, follow their instructions for donating.

steps.title: Use your trash can as a storage bin.
steps.content: Use your trash can as a storage bin. Depending how large your trash can is, you can bring it inside for clothes or other home storage. If it is too large to bring inside, store large garden tools like rakes and shovels and leave your trash can in your garage or yard. [2] X Research source

steps.title: Transform your trash can into a compost bin.
steps.content: Transform your trash can into a compost bin . Drill holes in the bottom and sides of the trash can to provide air. Add uncooked vegetable scraps, dried leaves, and plant material into the trash can. [3] X Research source Turn your compost every two weeks to keep it moist. Just put the lid on, turn it on its side, and roll it! Place your compost bin on bricks to increase air circulation. Use your compost to boost your gardening soil!

steps.title: Store pet food in your old trash can.
steps.content: Store pet food in your old trash can. If you have a dog or other large pet, use your old trash can to store pet food so you don’t have to run to the pet store as much. Buying pet food in bulk is also cheaper in the long run! Make sure your trash can is fully cleaned before storing food in it. [4] X Research source
